newsitem.title: USA: U.S. cash soymeal - Tight supplies push basis up.
newsitem.headline: U.S. cash soymeal - Tight supplies push basis up.

text.p: Cash soymeal basis offers were steady to higher on Tuesday as some U.S. Midwest processors scrounged for limited supplies, cash brokers said.
"Yields seem to be coming in fairly decent but a lot of soybeans are going into (storage) bins and a lot are going on barges to export markets," a Kentucky broker said.
Rail offers firmed $3.00 per ton in parts of Illinois while truck offers rose by $4.00.
While U.S. soybean harvest was 83 percent complete as of Sunday, processors were competing with elevators, river terminals and slow farmer selling for soybeans, brokers noted.
In many areas, farmers were storing soybeans in hopes of higher prices. CBOT soybean values have fallen more than $1.00 per bushel since July.
"Farmer selling is moderate at best," a broker said.
Brokers expected premiums to remain high through the end of the week. Forecasts called for widespread rain across the Midwest which should slow soybean harvest.
Spot truck soymeal basis (dollars per ton):
(Note: V=CBOT October futures, Z=CBOT December futures)
